awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Quantifying the roles of tectonic activity and climate as drivers of glacial-interglacial landscape evolution in the Teton Range, Wyoming
awd_abstract_narration:
The interplay of tectonics and climate is an essential aspect of mountain landscape evolution. Research efforts focusing on the interactions of mountain landscapes with climate and tectonism, especially those directed toward quantitative reconstructions of climatically and tectonically driven disturbances, are fundamental to understanding the past and future evolution of Earth's surface, and are critical for human adaptation and resource conservation efforts. This project focuses on the Teton mountain range in Grand Teton National Park, WY, where past climatic and tectonic disturbances are unusually well-recorded by glacial landforms, fault scarps, and lake sediment archives, all of which can be precisely dated. 

The overarching goals of this project are to quantify the influences of tectonic-driven disturbances (earthquakes, landslides) and climate-driven changes and disturbances (e.g. deglaciation, glacier fluctuations, vegetative shifts, fire occurrence) on alpine erosion rates and landscape evolution operating during the late Pleistocene and Holocene (past 25 ka). Specifically, the study combines detailed landform mapping, 10Be surface exposure dating, paleoseismic fault trenching, lake seismic surveys, and lake sediment cores to develop complementary records of: i) glacier fluctuations, including the timing and character of deglaciation and Neoglaciation; ii) environmental variability along the elevation gradient of the Teton range; and iii) earthquake timing and frequency related to postglacial ruptures of the Teton fault. The highly-active tectonic setting, distinctive geomorphology, and relatively pristine ecosystem of the Tetons present an exceptional opportunity for this research. Moreover, the integration of these techniques will provide comprehensive insights into the couplings and feedbacks among climatic and tectonic processes that modify all mountain landscapes over diverse length and time scales.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to quantify the role of tectonic and climatic processes in shaping mountain landscapes and in controlling the rates and magnitude of sediment production, transport, and deposition in alpine watersheds. Specifically, we performed an integrated, multidisciplinary study of the Teton fault and its interactions with the glacial and climatic history of the Teton Range in Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming, one of the nation?s classic glacio-tectonic mountain landscapes. Our research design sought to quantify the influence of tectonic-driven disturbances (earthquakes, landslides) and climate-driven changes and disturbances (e.g. glacier advances and retreat, hydroclimate variability) on alpine erosion rates and landscape evolution operating since the late Pleistocene (past ~25 ka). 

To accomplish the project goals, we employed a combination of detailed landform mapping, 10Be exposure dating, paleoseismic fault trenching, and lake sediment coring to develop complementary records of: i) glacier fluctuations, including the timing and character of deglaciation and Neoglaciation; ii) environmental variability along the elevation gradient of the Teton Range; and iii) earthquake timing and frequency related to postglacial ruptures of the Teton fault. By integrating these methods, we aimed to directly address the scientific priorities of the NSF-GLD program, particularly the investigation of couplings and feedbacks among climatic and tectonic processes that modify mountain landscapes over diverse length and time scales. The project outcomes fall into three broad categories: 1) chronologies of past glacial activity in Teton catchments, 2) the paleoseismic history and pattern of faulting along the Teton Fault, and 3) sedimentary records of past climate and alpine geomorphic processes.

Lake coring fieldwork was accomplished in six separate field expeditions. Through these efforts, we successfully recovered multiple overlapped lake sediment core sequences from several locations at each of five range-front terminal lakes (Phelps, Taggart, Bradley, Jenny, and Leigh Lakes) and four cirque lakes (Delta, Solitude, Omega, and Laurel Lakes). In total, ~200 meters of stratigraphic section were recovered. The cores range in length from ~3?15 m and most composite sections terminate in coarse sand and diamicton, which resemble ice-proximal sediments and suggest the records span the full post-glacial interval (e.g. past ~14 ka). Age control of the lake sediment sequences was established using a combination of radiocarbon dating (n = 148) and tephrochronology (n = 2). We analyzed multiple geochemical and physical sediment parameters to determine: 1) the precise timing and pattern of deglaciation of multiple Teton valleys, 2) the history of cirque glacier fluctuations during the Holocene, 3) latest Pleistocene and Holocene climate and environmental trends (and associated changes in sediment flux) at multiple elevations, and 4) the stratigraphic expression and timing of earthquake-generated turbidite deposits in all range-front terminal lakes. 

Exposure age dating campaigns targeted a series of glacial and tectonic landforms. We collected a total of ~70 samples from erratic boulders and bedrock surfaces for cosmogenic 10Be dating, which allowed us to reconstruct detailed chronologies of multiple adjacent terminal and lateral moraine systems spanning the Teton Range front. The sampling strategy included moraine complexes that are bisected directly by the fault. These valley glacier chronologies were integrated with precise geomorphic measurements of postglacial fault scarp offsets from field surveys, trench studies, and LiDAR analyses and augmented by basal radiocarbon ages and lithostratigraphy of sediments in glacially-scoured lake basins along elevation transects in corresponding catchments. Ages of glacial landforms have generated new knowledge on the glacial history of the Teton Range, which by extension has provided insight on the regional-scale climatic history of the northern Rocky Mountains. In addition, dating of landforms offset by the Teton fault have yielded vertical offset rates, contributing to our understanding of fault activity, seismic hazards, and landscape evolution in seismically active regions. 

We performed detailed mapping of the fault scarp and generated new records constraining the timing and frequency of large-magnitude, surface-rupturing earthquakes through multiple paleoseismic trench studies. We excavated two trenches near Ski Lake at the southern end of the Teton fault and found evidence for two late Quaternary surface faulting earthquakes. Age estimates for these events broadly overlap with events identified in earlier trenching studies along the fault to the north and will help guide estimates of fault rupture length. At our Antelope Flats paleoseismic study site, we excavated two trenches into a faulted late Quaternary outwash surface. The site investigated a fault that is antithetical to the main Teton fault and which might rupture along with the Teton fault during large earthquakes. Ages from the trench constrain deposition on the outwash surface and a single late Pleistocene to early Holocene surface faulting earthquake. 

Results from this project have been widely disseminated to professional communities, national park employees, and the general public through conference presentations, general audience talks, and organized field trips. The project also provided numerous and impactful training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers at three institutions.
